trans-unit.source: Provides a base control designer class for extending the design-mode behavior of a Web server control.

The ControlDesigner class provides a base control designer class that can be inherited from and extended to provide design-time support for a Web server control in a design host, such as [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)].

The object model for working with design-time rendering is improved over earlier versions, with the following new base classes to provide access to the simplified object model: - ControlDesigner, which is not new, but has been greatly improved.
- <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ContainerControlDesigner>.
- <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.CompositeControlDesigner>.

Automatic Formatting You can create a variety of automatic and pre-defined formats that can simplify the process of page developers who are applying complex style changes to custom Web server controls.
For example, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.TableDesigner> control, which derives from the ControlDesigner class, provides many automatic formats from which to choose.
To implement and provide automatic formatting in your custom controls, use the following features: - The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.AutoFormats%2A> property.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnAutoFormatApplied%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> class.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormatStyle> class.

Action Lists (Smart Tags) Action lists are menus of important or widely used tasks that a page developer who uses a control can perform in a design-time user interface (UI), such as [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)].
For example, the design-time view of your control could provide a menu of available tasks.
This includes a task to format the control automatically.
To learn about action lists, start with the following features: - The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ActionLists%2A> property.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionList> class.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionList.GetSortedActionItems%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionListCollection> class.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionMethodItem> class.
- The <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionPropertyItem> class.
Control Designer Regions Regions are editable areas in the design-time view of a Web server control.
This feature offers WYSIWYG-like editing of the template content, inner controls, and properties at design time.
You can have the control designer create controls in regions or you can use the Toolbox to drag and drop controls into regions.
Regions are managed with the following features: - The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnClick%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> class.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.EditableDesignerRegion> class.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method.
Templates The model for creating a UI for design-time editing of templated controls, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control, has been greatly improved from earlier versions.

You can create complex custom controls that include templates for various parts of the control, and your custom control designer can help page developers who are modifying templates with the following features: - The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.TemplateGroups%2A> property.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InTemplateMode%2A> property.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplateGroup> class.
Design-Time Rendering The ControlDesigner class has the following methods to support design-time rendering of the Web server control.
Most of these methods are the same as in earlier versions: - The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetEmptyDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UpdateDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreatePlaceHolderDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref> class.
Gets the action list collection for the control designer.

A <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionListCollection"></xref> object that contains the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionList"></xref> items for the control designer.
Gets a value indicating whether the control can be resized in the design-time environment.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if the control can be resized; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets the collection of predefined automatic formatting schemes to display in the **Auto Format** dialog box for the associated control at design time.

A complete Web server control includes not only the control, but also, possibly, a corresponding control designer class that is derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class and a formatting class that is derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> class.
The AutoFormats property is a collection of instances of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> class.
For a working example of automatic formatting in [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)], see <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Calendar>.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormatCollection"></xref> object that contains the predefined schemes for the control.
Creates HTML markup to display a specified error message at design time.
Use the CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml method to create HTML markup to display an error message for a control at design time.
The value for `errorMessage` specifies a localized string that is displayed to the user of the control at design time.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class implementation of the CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml method returns a table with two rows, as follows: - The first row contains the type name and site name for the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> object.
- The second row contains the input error message string.

To generate HTML markup for an error message with an associated exception, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml%28System.String%2CSystem.Exception%29> overload.
To generate HTML markup for an exception without specifying a localized error message, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
The error message to include in the generated HTML markup.
An HTML markup string that contains the specified error message.
Creates the HTML markup to display a specified exception error message at design time.
Use the CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml method to provide simple HTML markup that can be used to display error and exception details for a control at design time.
The value for `errorMessage` specifies a localized string that is displayed to the user of the control at design time.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class implementation of the CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml method returns a table with two rows, as follows: - The first row contains the type name and site name for the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner>object.
- The second row contains the input error message and the <xref:System.Exception.Message%2A> string of the exception.
To generate HTML markup for an error message without specifying an exception, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.CreateErrorDesignTimeHtml%28System.String%29> overload.
To generate HTML markup for an exception without specifying a localized error message, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetErrorDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
The error message to include in the generated HTML string.
The exception to include in the generated HTML string.
HTML markup that contains the specified errorMessage and e.
Provides a simple rectangular placeholder representation that displays the type and ID of the control.
A string that contains design-time HTML markup providing basic information about the control.
Provides a simple rectangular placeholder representation that displays the type and ID of the control, and also additional specified instructions or information.
A string that contains text and markup to add to the HTML output.
A string that contains design-time HTML markup providing information about the control.
Returns a copy of the associated control for viewing or rendering on the design surface.
A Web server control.
Gets a value indicating whether data binding is supported by the containing region for the associated control.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if the container for the control supports data binding; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets an object that is used to persist data for the associated control at design time.
The values for the DesignerState property are persisted even if the user switches from Design to Source view, or reloads the document, or closes and reopens the design host.
You can get and set values in the returned object as you would in an IDictionary object, with the values automatically persisted.

A DesignerState property that implements <xref:System.Collections.IDictionary> and uses the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.IComponentDesignerStateService"></xref> to persist state data for the associated control at design time.
Gets the view-control object for the control designer.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value indicating whether the design host must finish loading before the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml*> method can be called.
The default implementation of the DesignTimeHtmlRequiresLoadComplete property returns `false`.
> [!NOTE] > The DesignTimeHtmlRequiresLoadComplete property is obsolete.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetViewFlags%2A> method for equivalent control designer functionality.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if loading must be complete before the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml*> method can be called; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Retrieves the coordinates of the rectangle representing the boundaries for the control as displayed on the design surface.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Rectangle"></xref> object representing the boundaries for the control on the design surface relative to the control, not the document.
Retrieves the HTML markup that is used to represent the control at design time.
The HTML markup used to represent the control at design time.
Retrieves the HTML markup to display the control and populates the collection with the current control designer regions.
The design host calls the GetDesignTimeHtml method to get the design-time HTML markup and the current list of control designer regions.
Using the DesignerRegionCollection, the design host can then request the markup for each editable control designer region.

The GetDesignTimeHtml method is provided for a derived control designer, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.GridViewDesigner> class, that must process the content for the region before calling the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
A collection of control designer regions for the associated control.
The design-time HTML markup for the associated control, including all control designer regions.
Returns an appropriate resource provider factory, depending on the globalization settings in the configuration file for the site.

A resource provider factory creates resource providers and resource writers, depending on the current settings in the system.web/globalization section of the configuration file (either the Machine.config or Web.config files for both global and local resources).

If no globalization settings are found, the `serviceProvider` parameter is used to create a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignTimeResourceProviderFactory> object using the default implementation for the design host.
Typically, control developers will not override the GetDesignTimeResourceProviderFactory method.
An <xref:System.IServiceProvider> object that can retrieve global and local services.

A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.DesignTimeResourceProviderFactory"></xref> object, if any are defined in the configuration file; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
Returns the content for an editable region of the design-time view of the associated control.
The default implementation of the GetEditableDesignerRegionContent method returns an empty string ("").

Classes deriving from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class can support region-based editing on the design surface and override the GetEditableDesignerRegionContent method to return the content for a specified region.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.EditableDesignerRegion"></xref> object to get content for.
The persisted content for the region, if the control designer supports editable regions; otherwise, an empty string ("").
Retrieves the HTML markup to represent a Web server control at design time that will have no visual representation at run time.
The default behavior of the GetEmptyDesignTimeHtml method is to return a string that contains the name of the component.
The GetEmptyDesignTimeHtml method should be called in the implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method when there is no design-time HTML markup.
The HTML markup used to represent a control at design time that would otherwise have no visual representation.
The default is a rectangle that contains the type and ID of the component.
Retrieves the HTML markup that provides information about the specified exception.
The GetErrorDesignTimeHtml method is typically called, if an exception is thrown in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
The exception that occurred.
The design-time HTML markup for the specified exception.
Retrieves the persistable inner HTML markup of the control at design time.
A string representing the persistable inner HTML markup for the associated control.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
Retrieves the persistable inner HTML markup of the control.
The persistable inner HTML markup of the control.
Retrieves an object that contains the design-time markup for the content and regions of the associated control.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.ViewRendering"></xref> object.
Retrieves an object that contains the design-time markup for the content and regions of the specified control.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control"></xref> object.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.ViewRendering"></xref> object.
Retrieves an object that contains the design-time markup for the content and regions of the associated control for the specified control designer.
A control designer that derives from <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.ViewRendering"></xref> object.
Gets a value indicating whether the properties of the associated control are hidden when the control is in template mode.
The ID property is never hidden.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.PreFilterProperties%2A> method uses the HidePropertiesInTemplateMode property to determine whether properties, other than the ID property, should be hidden from the property grids while the control is in template editing mode.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if the properties of the associated control are hidden when the control is in template mode; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
Gets or sets the ID string for the control.
The ID property is used internally within the control designer and for interaction with the Properties window.
The ID property shadows the run-time <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property.
The ID string for the control.
Initializes the control designer and loads the specified component.
The Initialize method is called by the design host to complete the following actions: - Load the control designer with the component to design.
- Set up the view on the control using the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetViewFlags%2A> method.
- Verify that the associated control is of the right type.
The control being designed.
Gets a value indicating whether the control is in either template viewing or editing mode in the design host.
The InTemplateMode property is read-only.

A Web server control is in template mode when a read-only template is currently being viewed or an editable template is being edited in a design host such as [!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)].

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class supplies a default <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ViewEventHandler> object to update the InTemplateMode value when the template mode changes for the associated control.

Custom designers that are derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplatedControlDesigner> class can override the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplatedControlDesigner.OnTemplateModeChanged%2A> method to perform additional processing when the template editing mode changes for a control in the design host.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if the control is in either template viewing or editing mode; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Invalidates the whole area of the control that is displayed on the design surface and signals the control designer to redraw the control.

To enable the control designer to handle paint events, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetViewFlags%2A> method in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Initialize%2A> method.
The Invalidate method provides the design host with a way to instruct the control designer to redraw the control.
Essentially, this is the same as calling <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UpdateDesignTimeHtml%2A> method, because it causes the whole control to be redrawn.
Invalidates the specified area of the control that is displayed on the design surface and signals the control designer to redraw the control.

To enable the control designer to handle paint events, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetViewFlags%2A> method in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Initialize%2A> method.
The Invalidate method provides the design host with a way to instruct the control designer to redraw a specific part of the control.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Rectangle"></xref> object that represents the area to invalidate, relative to the upper-left corner of the control.
Wraps a series of changes into a transaction, using the specified parameters that can be rolled back as a unit with the undo functionality of the design host.

The implementation of the InvokeTransactedChange method notifies the design host, which is determined by the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Site%2A> property of `component`, that a change is occurring in the associated control and, if the change is not canceled by the design host, invokes the specified `callback` using the specified `context`, and then notifies the design host that the change has completed.

If the design host or the associated control throws a static `Canceled` exception field of a <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.CheckoutException> exception, the transaction is canceled without invoking `callback`.
The control associated with the control designer.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.TransactedChangeCallback"></xref> object representing a function to call in the control designer as part of the transaction.
An object that contains the argument for callback.
A description of the effect of allowing the transaction to complete, which is used by the design host to give the user an opportunity to cancel the transaction.
component is .
-or- callback is .
Wraps a series of changes into a transaction, using the specified parameters that can be rolled back as a unit with the undo functionality of the design host.

The implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InvokeTransactedChange%2A> method notifies the design host, which is determined by the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Site%2A> property of `component`, that a change is occurring to the specified `member` (property or method) of the associated control and, if the change is not canceled by the design host, invokes the specified `callback` using the specified `context` as the argument, and then notifies the design host that the change has completed.

If the design host or associated control throws a static `Canceled` exception field of a <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.CheckoutException> exception, the transaction is canceled without invoking `callback`.
The control associated with the control designer.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.TransactedChangeCallback"></xref> object representing a function to call in the control designer as part of the transaction.
An object that contains the argument for callback.
A description of the effect of allowing the transaction to complete, which is used by the design host to give the user an opportunity to cancel the transaction.

A <xref href="System.ComponentModel.MemberDescriptor"></xref> object (typically, either an <xref href="System.ComponentModel.EventDescriptor"></xref> or a <xref href="System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor"></xref> object) that describes the member of the associated control that is being invoked as part of the transaction.
component is .
-or- callback is .
Wraps a series of changes into a transaction, using the specified parameters that can be rolled back as a unit with the undo functionality of the design host.

The implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InvokeTransactedChange%2A> method notifies the design host, which is represented by `serviceProvider`, that a change is occurring to the specified `member` (property or method) of the associated control and, if the change is not canceled by the design host, invokes the specified `callback` using the specified `context` as the argument, and then notifies the design host that the change has completed.

If the design host or the associated control throws a static `Canceled` exception field of a <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.CheckoutException> exception, the transaction is canceled without invoking `callback`.
An <xref:System.IServiceProvider> object representing the design host that provides control designer services for the associated control.
The control associated with the control designer.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.TransactedChangeCallback"></xref> object representing a function to call in the control designer as part of the transaction.
An object that contains the argument for callback.
A description of the effect of allowing the transaction to complete, which is used by the design host to give the user an opportunity to cancel the transaction.

A <xref href="System.ComponentModel.MemberDescriptor"></xref> object (typically either an <xref href="System.ComponentModel.EventDescriptor"></xref> or a <xref href="System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor"></xref> object) that describes the member of the associated control that is being invoked as part of the transaction.
component is .
-or- callback is .
-or- serviceProvider is .
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Web server control has been marked as changed.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if the Web server control has changed since it was last persisted or loaded; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Retrieves a value indicating whether the specified property on the associated control is data-bound.
The property to test for data binding.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if the property is data-bound; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Uses the provided resource writer to persist the localizable properties of the associated control to a resource in the design host.

The Localize method is called by the design host to create resource entries for each property that is marked with a <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> object and any properties that use an explicit resource expression as a value.
An object derived from the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.IDesignTimeResourceWriter"></xref> object that is used to write resources into the design-time response stream.
Called when a predefined, automatic formatting scheme has been applied to the associated control.
The OnAutoFormatApplied method is called after a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> object has applied a predefined format to the associated control.
A <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat> object defines the automatic formatting scheme name and style settings that are applied to the control.

Classes deriving from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class override the OnAutoFormatApplied method to perform additional processing when an automatic formatting scheme is applied to the associated control.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerAutoFormat"></xref> object that defines a style.
Called when the data-binding collection changes.
The OnBindingsCollectionChanged method is called when the data-binding collection has been changed by an external caller.
> [!NOTE] > The OnBindingsCollectionChanged method is obsolete.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.DataBindingCollection.Changed> event on the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.HtmlControlDesigner.DataBindings%2A> collection for equivalent control designer functionality.
The property to test for changes in its bindings collection.
Called by the design host when the user clicks the associated control at design time.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerView.ViewEvent> event is raised by the design host for certain actions on a control in the design surface.
For example, an event is raised for the following conditions: - The user clicks the control.
- The control designer paints on the design surface.
- The user enters or exits template editing mode for the control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class supplies a default delegate to handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerView.ViewEvent?displayProperty=fullName> event.
Classes deriving from <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> override the OnClick method to process events that are raised when the user clicks a control.
The OnClick method allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
The default implementation of the OnClick method returns without performing any processing.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegionMouseEventArgs"></xref> object that specifies the location and, possibly, the control designer region that the user clicked.
Called when the associated control changes.
The OnComponentChanged method is called when a property on the associated control is changed.
It allows the implementer to do any processing that might be required after a property change.
Calling the OnComponentChanged method causes the design host to call the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method.
The base implementation of the OnComponentChanged method also persists the control in the page markup.
The source of the event.
A <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentChangedEventArgs"></xref> object that contains the event data.
Represents the method that will handle the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.IComponentChangeService.ComponentChanging"></xref> event for the associated control.

When either the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.InvokeTransactedChange%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.Localize%2A> method is called, the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IComponentChangeService.ComponentChanging> event occurs before any changes are made to the associated control.
After the changes are complete, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnComponentChanged%2A> method occurs.
The object that is the source of the event.
A <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentChangedEventArgs"></xref> object that contains the event data.
Called when the associated Web server control has been resized in the design host at design time.
> [!NOTE] > The OnControlResize method is obsolete.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnComponentChanged%2A> method for equivalent control designer functionality.
The OnControlResize method typically is called only by the design-time environment when a user action causes the associated Web server control to be resized.
The OnControlResize method might be called several times during a resizing process to display the updated size of the control before the resizing is completed.
The width and height properties of the control are updated before the OnControlResize method is called.

Called when the control designer draws the associated control on the design surface, if the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.ViewFlags"></xref> value is <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerView.ViewEvent> event is raised by the design host for certain actions on a control in the design surface.
For example, an event is raised for the following conditions: - The user clicks the control.
- The design host requests HTML markup to render the associated control on the design surface.
- The user enters or exits template editing mode for the control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class supplies a default delegate to handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerView.ViewEvent?displayProperty=fullName> event.

Classes deriving from <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> should set the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ViewFlags?displayProperty=fullName> value and override the OnPaint method to process events that are raised when the design host draws the control on the design surface.
The OnPaint method allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
The default implementation of the OnPaint method returns without performing any processing.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs"></xref> object that specifies the graphics and rectangle boundaries used to draw the control.
Adds properties to or removes properties from the Properties grid in a design host at design time or provides new design-time properties that might correspond to properties on the associated control.
With the PreFilterProperties method, you can add items to the dictionary of properties that a control designer exposes through a <xref:System.ComponentModel.TypeDescriptor> object.
The keys in the dictionary of properties are the names of the properties.
The objects are of type <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor>.
The properties for the class of the component.
Raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.OnControlResize*> event.
The RaiseResizeEvent method is obsolete and there is no replacement for this feature.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the properties of the control are read-only at design time.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class is read-only, by nature.
Read/write features are provided by adding a <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.DesignerRegion> object or using base classes, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ContainerControlDesigner> class.
> [!NOTE] > The ReadOnly property is obsolete.

Derive from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ContainerControlDesigner> class to which you can add editable designer regions or from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.TemplatedControlDesigner> object to which you can create editable designer regions in templates.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if the properties of the control are read-only at design time; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Registers internal data in a cloned control.
Whenever an item is cloned, there might be some internal data structures, such as `meta:` attributes, that should be included in the cloned control by the control designer.
A page developer might add `meta:` attributes to the markup of a control and there is no way, nor is there a reason, for the control to distinguish what those tags might be.

Therefore, if your control designer provides a way to edit complex properties or formats before applying changes to a page, you would create a clone of the control, pass both the original control and the clone to this RegisterClone method, and then, when the changes are persisted to the tag, all `meta:` attributes are also persisted.
The control associated with the control designer.
The cloned copy of the associated control.
original is null.
-or- clone is null.
Gets the control designer for the Web Forms page that contains the associated control.
The RootDesigner property represents the control designer for the Web Forms page that contains the control.
Use the RootDesigner property to access and manipulate the containing Web Forms page at design time.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.WebFormsRootDesigner"></xref> object that can be used at design time to access components on the Web Forms page that contains the control.
Specifies the content for an editable region of the control at design time.

Classes deriving from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class can support region-based editing on the design surface and override the SetEditableDesignerRegionContent method to set the content for a specified region.
An editable design region contained within the control.
The content to assign for the editable design region.
Specifies the content for an editable region in the design-time view of the control.
Normally, the SetRegionContent method is not overridden in derived designers.
The base class causes the design host to call the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method for the region.
Override the SetRegionContent method when custom data is required for the control before calling <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.SetEditableDesignerRegionContent%2A> method.
Use the SetRegionContent method to insert HTML markup into a region of the control.
An editable design region contained within the design-time view of the control.
The content to assign for the editable design region.
Assigns the specified bitwise <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.ViewFlags"></xref> enumeration to the specified flag value.
There are several flags that can be set.

For example, use the SetViewFlags method to set the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ViewFlags> value of the current <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property for the control designer, instead of the obsolete <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.DesignTimeHtmlRequiresLoadComplete%2A> property.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.ViewFlags"></xref> value.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> to set the flag, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref> to remove the flag.
Gets an object representing the HTML markup element for the associated control.
Typically, the Tag property is used only for communication between the design host and the control designer and is not used by control developers.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.IControlDesignerTag"></xref> object that represents the HTML markup element for the associated control.
Gets a collection of template groups, each containing one or more template definitions.
A collection of <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.TemplateGroup"></xref> objects.
The default is an empty <xref href="System.Web.UI.Design.TemplateGroupCollection"></xref>.
Refreshes the design-time HTML markup for the associated Web server control by calling the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml*> method.
The UpdateDesignTimeHtml method is called by the design host to update the display of the associated Web server control at design time, such as when the control has been modified.
Also, a control designer can call the UpdateDesignTimeHtml method after modifying values of the control to update the display of the control.

> [!NOTE] > If you are calling the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IComponentChangeService.ComponentChanged> event, or using the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor> object to set properties, the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IComponentChangeService> interface calls the UpdateDesignTimeHtml method for you.
Gets a value indicating whether the control designer uses a temporary preview control to generate the design-time HTML markup.
If the UsePreviewControl property is `true`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property returns a temporary copy of the control.
Changes to the temporary control are not persisted to the document.

If the UsePreviewControl property is `false`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property returns an instance of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component%2A> property for the control.
Changes to the instance of the control are persisted.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> setting in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> object is used to set the value of the UsePreviewControl property.

Therefore, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> setting determines the type of control that is returned by the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property in the base <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> is not specified in the control designer declaration, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> object behavior is equivalent to specifying the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> property as `false`.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if the control designer uses a temporary copy of the control for design-time preview; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>, if the control designer uses the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component*> property for the control contained in the control designer.
Gets or sets a Web server control that can be used for previewing the design-time HTML markup.
The ViewControl property uses the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property to determine its return value.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property is `true`, the ViewControl property returns a temporary copy of the control.
Changes to the temporary control are not persisted.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property is `false`, the ViewControl property returns an instance of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.Component%2A> property for the control.
Changes to the instance of the control are persisted.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> setting in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> object is used to set the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property.

Therefore, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> setting determines the type of control that is returned by the ViewControl property in the base <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> class.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute> is not specified in the control designer declaration, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner> object behavior is equivalent to specifying the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.SupportsPreviewControlAttribute.SupportsPreviewControl%2A> property as `false`.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control"></xref> object used by the base class to generate design-time HTML markup.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether a <xref uid="langword_csharp_View" name="View" href=""></xref> control has been created for display on the design surface.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>, if a control has been created for viewing on the design surface; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the control is visible at design time.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> in all cases.
